DAVID MARSHALL STEWART
NASHVILLE PUBLIC LIBRARY
222 EIGHTH AVENUE. NORTH
NASHVILLE 3. TENNESSEE
June 23, 1967
The Hon, Dan Kuykendall
The United States Congress
House of Representatives
Wasnington, D, C, 20002
Dear Congressman Kuykendall:
There is presently before the Committee on Interstate and Foreign
Commerce bill H.R. 6736 for action by the House on S. 1160, The
Public Broadcasting Act of 1967, passed by the Senate, You are
perhaps aware of the efforts during the past five year3 to establish
a state wide system of educational television stations in Tennessee,
some of which are already on the air. There is a great deal yet to
be dona in this area alone.
There is presently under way a study toward establishing a state
network- of educational radio stations in Tennessee. This study is
being conducted by the University of Tennessee under the sponsor¬
ship of various educational institutions from across the 3tate,
represented in your area by iiemphis State University, and Christian
Brothers College who is now attempting to construct such a station.
Representatives of these and other educational institutions in
Tennessee met in Nashville in January of this year to initiate this
study and informally organized themselves into the Tennessee
Educational Broadcasters Association for the purpose of establishing
the Tennessee Educational Radio Network. The purpose of the study
iSj4° de^ena^n0 specific needs of the State for an educational
radio network with recommendations for location in areas not now
being served and programming to be presented. There is much work
to oe done and much financial assistance will be needed.
The Rublic Broadcasting Act of 1967 will provide assistance in this
project. e urge you to make a special effort to see that your
committee and the House take action on this bill in the present
session and that the needs of Tennessee are included in the final
legislation.
Yours sincerely.
Alvin L. Bolt, Supervising
Audio-Visual Librarian and
Mgr. of Radio Station WPLN
